title: The Oscars Are Headed to YouTube After ABC Deal Ends
summary: The Academy Awards are moving to YouTube starting in 2029, the film academy announced Wednesday, marking a new era for Hollywood’s leading awards show and a mainstay of network television for decades
story: The Academy Awards are moving to YouTube starting in 2029, the film academy announced Wednesday, marking a new era for Hollywood’s leading awards show and a mainstay of network television for decades.

The deal between the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and YouTube will start with the 101st Oscars ceremony in 2029 and run through 2033. The telecast has aired live on ABC since the 1970s.

“We are thrilled to enter into a multifaceted global partnership with YouTube to be the future home of the Oscars and our year-round Academy programming,” Academy CEO Bill Kramer and Academy President Lynette Howell Taylor said in a joint statement.

“The Academy is an international organization, and this partnership will allow us to expand access to the work of the Academy to the largest worldwide audience possible — which will be beneficial for our Academy members and the film community,” Kramer and Taylor said.

The two academy leaders said the partnership would “leverage YouTube’s vast reach and infuse the Oscars and other Academy programming with innovative opportunities for engagement while honoring our legacy.”

The deal symbolizes YouTube’s growing dominance in the television and video ecosystem — and Hollywood’s recognition of digital media’s power. The platform, which is owned by the technology behemoth YouTube, represented the largest share of U.S. streaming television viewing last month, according to Nielsen, a leading measurement firm.
Oscars ratings have generally declined since peaking in 1998, the year “Titanic” conquered the ceremony, winning 11 trophies and helping draw in 55 million viewers.

The most recent telecast brought in nearly 20 million viewers — a slight improvement over Covid-era installments, but still a fraction of the audience that tuned in for the ceremony at the height of its commercial and cultural power.

“The Oscars are one of our essential cultural institutions, honoring excellence in storytelling and artistry,” YouTube CEO Neal Mohan said in a statement. “Partnering with the Academy to bring this celebration of art and entertainment to viewers all over the world will inspire a new generation of creativity and film lovers while staying true to the Oscars’ storied legacy.”

The ceremony — including red carpet coverage, behind-the-scenes programming — will be available live and for free to viewers around the world, as well as to YouTube TV subscribers in the United States, according to the academy.
This story originally appeared on NBCNews.com.

title: Tonight's 'Survivor' Finale Will Be Interrupted by a Presidential Address. But for How Long?
summary: What time is the Survivor finale on? How long will the interruption be?
story: The season finale of “Survivor,” scheduled to air Dec. 17, will feature a bit of a hitch when President Trump will interrupt the broadcast to deliver a primetime address to the nation.
The final episode of the 49th season of the long-running reality TV staple is scheduled to run for three hours, but the president’s speech will bump the timeline for viewers.
There are five castaways remaining in the quest to outwit, outplay and outlast each other for the $1 million grand prize:

Kristina Mills, 36, Edmond, Oklahoma, MBA career coachRizo Velovic, 25, Yonkers, New York, tech salesSage Ahrens-Nichols, 30, Olympia, Washington, clinical social workerSavannah Louie, 31, Atlanta, former reporterSophi Balerdi, 27, Miami, entrepreneur
Kristina Mills, 36, Edmond, Oklahoma, MBA career coach
Rizo Velovic, 25, Yonkers, New York, tech sales
Sage Ahrens-Nichols, 30, Olympia, Washington, clinical social worker
Savannah Louie, 31, Atlanta, former reporter
Sophi Balerdi, 27, Miami, entrepreneur
Here’s wat you need to know about how to watch the “Survivor” finale.
What time is the 'Survivor' finale?
The “Survivor” finale will air Dec. 17 at 8 p.m. ET/PT on CBS.
When will the 'Survivor' finale be interrupted?

“CBS News will air a Special Report for President Donald J. Trump’s live primetime address to the nation from the White House, Wednesday, Dec. 17 at 9:00 p.m. ET,” Paramount, which owns CBS, said in a statement.

The schedule on the CBS website lists the “Survivor” finale starting at 8 p.m. ET, with the president’s speech beginning at 9 p.m. ET and a resumption of the finale at 9:22 p.m. ET, at which point it will run for two more hours, concluding at 11 p.m. ET.
When will the 'Survivor' finale return?
The episode will continue after the president finishes his speech.

CBS says the finale “will resume where it left off immediately following the president’s address for Eastern and Central Time Zone viewers on the CBS Television Network and air in its entirety. Check your local listings for more details.”
It should be noted no other time zones were mentioned.

title: Willie Shares How He Got to Meet Taylor Swift — And Why Jenna Missed Out
summary: Willie Geist just lived Jenna Bush Hager’s wildest dream, and she now has a major case of FOMO
story: Willie Geist just lived Jenna Bush Hager’s wildest dream, and she now has a major case of FOMO.
While appearing as a guest co-host on TODAY with Jenna & Friends Dec. 17, Willie shared a photo of himself meeting Taylor Swift at a screening for the singer’s “End of an Era” docuseries.
The six-part Disney+ documentary gives fans a behind-the-scenes look at what it took to put together Swift’s iconic “Eras Tour.”

“It’s amazing. If you’ve been to the show, or even if you haven’t been, what went into making that show and pulling it off every night and everything they went through over the course of the tour, it’s incredible,” Willie explained.
The Sunday TODAY host had attended an “Eras Tour” concert with his daughter, so when he was invited to a screening of the docuseries, he jumped at the opportunity to check it out.

“So you go to the screening room downtown in New York. We’re sitting there getting ready to watch the show. Door opens. Taylor Swift walks in the room to thank everyone for coming. Not only that, she sat with us for the entire show, two episodes, and all of her dancers from the tour — including Kam (Saunders) — were all there,” Willie said.
“Kam was there?” Jenna asked.

“Kam was there — and they’re all cheering for each other when they see their friends on the screen because a lot of the series is about them. She highlights not just her but all the people in the show,” Willie said.
After the screening ended, Willie got a special opportunity to meet Swift.

“She was nice enough to take a couple of pictures with some people, and I posted it (on Instagram) because the series was great,” Willie said. “And wow, people really respond to a Taylor Swift photo.”
Turns out, Jenna had the opportunity to go too, but had to turn down the invite. She blamed it on Jenna & Friends’ “mother,” aka executive producer Talia Parkinson-Jones.

“We had a lot of stuff going on that day, a lot of work stuff, so I wrote my mother, Talia Parkinson-Jones, our boss, and I said, ‘Is there any way — please, mother! — is there any way I can move things around?’ And she wrote back, ‘Gosh, I really wish I could say yes, but the answer is no,’” she recalled.
Naturally, Jenna was a little jealous to hear about Willie’s experience at the screening.
“So when you’re telling me all these things, and even when I saw that Instagram, the FOMO was deep,” she said.
“It hurts, doesn’t it?” Willie quipped.
“I mean, she was looking out for the show, but that was my chance,” Jenna said.
“Well, hopefully you’ll have more chances,” he said.
“That was my chance to hang out with Taylor,” Jenna added.
Willie and Jenna then agreed that maybe Swift should just visit Jenna & Friends and Sunday TODAY
“That’s a good package put together,” Willie said.
“Let’s put the pitch together,” Jenna said. “But anyway, Taylor, I love you, and I’m sorry I wasn’t able to come. My mother told me I couldn’t.”

title: 'Emily in Paris' Is Almost Back! Here's When Season 5 Premieres
summary: What time does Emily in Paris return to Netflix in Season 5? When does the new season of Emily in Paris premiere? Here's how to watch Emily in Paris on December 18.
story: Emily Cooper is about to live la dolce vita in Season 5 of "Emily in Paris."
The hit Netflix series returns to the streaming service for another highly anticipated batch of episodes this week, and finds the fashionable expat living it up in Rome.
Before Season 5 premieres, we're breaking down everything you need to know before tuning in.
What Time Does ‘Emily in Paris’ Season 5 Land on Netflix?
All 10 episodes of "Emily in Paris" Season 5 will premiere globally on Netflix on Thursday, Dec. 18 at 12:01 a.m. PT, so about 3 a.m. ET.
What Will Happen in Season 5 of 'Emily in Paris'?
At the end of Season 4, Emily (Lily Collins) found herself in Rome visiting her new love interest, a handsome Italian named Marcello (Eugenio Franceschini).
Emily's boss, Sylvie (Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu), was determined to take on Marcello's family company as a client for Agence Grateau so she crashed the trip.
Ultimately, the family agreed to give the PR agency a try and Sylvie asked Emily to stay in Rome to run the account and head Agence Grateau's new Rome office.
A trailer for Season 5 shows Emily enjoying her new life in Rome and mixing business with pleasure with Marcello by her side.
Emily started her European journey in Paris and the trailer hints that she'll be returning to Paris at some point this season as Sylvie says, "I need my Emily in Paris."

Emily may be happy with Marcello, but her on again, off again relationship with Gabriel (Lucas Bravo) is ever present, and the French chef makes an appearance in the trailer as he hugs Emily at a train station.
Meanwhile, Emily's ex Alfie (Lucien Laviscount) and her bestie Mindy (Ashley Park) seem to be getting cozy in one scene as they nearly lock lips.
Who's Returning for Season 5?

Camille Razat, who played Gabriel's ex Camille in Seasons 1 to 4, announced that she was leaving the show earlier this year. However, many familiar faces will return for Season 5, including the following:

title: 'The Voice' Season 28 Winner Is Crowned. Find Out Who Won
summary: “The Voice” Season 28 officially has a winner. After a two-night live finale, one artist and coach won the season.
story: “The Voice” Season 28 officially has a winner.

All season long, contestants have been vying for a spot on coaches Michael Bublé, Snoop Dogg, Niall Horan and Reba McEntire’s teams. Last week, four of the six finalists were officially announced, while the last two additional contestants — chosen by viewers — were revealed during the Dec. 15 episode.

Heading into the finale, each coach had at least one singer in the game: Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba), Aiden Ross (Team Niall), Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé), Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop), Max Chambers (Team Bublé) and Dek of Hearts (Team Niall).

Host Carson Daly welcomed special guests and past winners to the stage over the two nights, as well as the final six artists, who delivered their best performances in hopes of being crowned “The Voice” Season 28 winner in the Dec. 16 episode.
Read the two-part recap and find out the winner, below.
What Happened During ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Part 1?
During the Monday, Dec. 15 episode, 14-year-old Max Chambers from Team Bublé and trio Dek of Hearts from Team Niall were revealed as the final two singers competing in the finale.
Here is what they all performed:

Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Fishin’ in the Dark” by Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and “Let It Go” by James Bay.Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang Forrest Frank’s “Your Way’s Better” and Whitney Houston’s “One Moment In Time.”
Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Fishin’ in the Dark” by Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and “Let It Go” by James Bay.
Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang Forrest Frank’s “Your Way’s Better” and Whitney Houston’s “One Moment In Time.”

Team Reba’s Aubrey Nicole sang “‘Til You Can’t“ by Cody Johnson and “The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia,” originally sung by Vicki Lawrence and re-recorded by McEntire in 1991.Team Bublé’s Jazz McKenzie sang “Against All Odds” by Phil Collins and “Drivers License” by Olivia Rodrigo.Team Niall’s Aiden Ross sang “Golden Hour” by JVKE and “The Winner Takes It All” by ABBA.Team Snoop’s Ralph Edwards sang Foreigner’s “I Want to Know What Love Is” and Bruno Mars’ “Locked Out of Heaven.”
Team Reba’s Aubrey Nicole sang “‘Til You Can’t“ by Cody Johnson and “The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia,” originally sung by Vicki Lawrence and re-recorded by McEntire in 1991.
Team Bublé’s Jazz McKenzie sang “Against All Odds” by Phil Collins and “Drivers License” by Olivia Rodrigo.
Team Niall’s Aiden Ross sang “Golden Hour” by JVKE and “The Winner Takes It All” by ABBA.
Team Snoop’s Ralph Edwards sang Foreigner’s “I Want to Know What Love Is” and Bruno Mars’ “Locked Out of Heaven.”
What Happened During ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Part 2?

Eliminated contestants, along with artists like XG, Khalid, Riley Green, Zac Brown, Noah Cyrus, Neal Schon and Journey, and the coaches took the stage. “The Voice” Season 26 winner Sofronio Vasquez also delivered a special performance.

For the second night of the finale, the final contestants got the chance to perform with their coach. Unfortunately, due to health issues and doctor’s orders, Horan was unable to sing with his finalists. McEntire stepped in to perform with Dek of Hearts, while past Team Niall Season 23 winner Gina Miles sang with Ross.
Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Santa Claus Is Coming to Town” with McEntire.Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang “Blue Christmas” with his coach.
Team Niall’s Dek of Hearts sang “Santa Claus Is Coming to Town” with McEntire.
Team Bublé’s Max Chambers sang “Blue Christmas” with his coach.

Team Reba’s Aubrey Nicole sang “Mary, Did You Know?” with her coach.Team Niall’s Aiden Ross sang “Last Christmas” with Miles.Team Bublé’s Jazz McKenzie sang “Jingle Bell Rock” with her coach.Team Snoop’s Ralph Edwards sang “This Christmas” with his coach.
Team Reba’s Aubrey Nicole sang “Mary, Did You Know?” with her coach.
Team Niall’s Aiden Ross sang “Last Christmas” with Miles.
Team Bublé’s Jazz McKenzie sang “Jingle Bell Rock” with her coach.
Team Snoop’s Ralph Edwards sang “This Christmas” with his coach.
Who Was 'The Voice' Season 28 Winner?
The winner for Season 28 of “The Voice” was Aiden Ross. This was Team Niall's third win.
In second place was Team Snoop's Ralph Edwards.
Dek of Hearts came in third, while Aubrey Nicole came in fourth. In fifth place was Max Chambers and Jazz McKenzie in sixth.
Who Are the Coaches for ‘The Voice’ Season 29?
Season 29 of “The Voice” is following a different format. Titled “The Voice: Battle of Champions,” Adam Levine, Kelly Clarkson and John Legend will return as the three coaches, instead of four.
The new version will also include the return of “The Voice” alumni, super steals, new voting rules and more changes that the coaches can use to their advantage.
“The Voice: Battle of Champions,” Season 29, premieres Monday, Feb. 23 at 9 p.m. ET on NBC.

title: When and How to Watch 'The Voice' Season 28 Finale
summary: 'The Voice' Season 28 finale takes place Monday Dec. 15, 2025. Find out how to watch on NBC, stream online, and what time both nights air.
story: Season 28 of ‘The Voice” is almost coming to an end.

This season has been jam-packed with powerhouse performances and emotional eliminations since its Sept. 22 premiere. Now, the competition's top six contestants are delivering their final performances in hopes of being crowned the winner.
The first four final contestants were announced last week. Two additional contestants — chosen by viewers — were revealed during the part one live finale on Dec. 15.
The results of the voting will be revealed tonight, Dec. 16, during the star-studded finale episode, which features performances by girl group XG and singer Khalid.

Only one artist — and that artist's coach — will be crowned the winner. Will two-time champion coaches Michael Bublé or Niall Horan win for the third time? Or will they be bested by one of their fellow judges, Reba McEntire or Snoop Dogg?
Here's everything to know about the Season 28 finale.
What Time Does ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale Air?
Part one of the two-night finale of “The Voice” aired at 9 p.m. ET on Dec. 15. The second final episode will air also at 9 p.m. ET on Dec. 16.
Where to Watch ‘The Voice’ Season 28 Finale
Viewers can watch the episodes live on NBC. Each episode will be available to stream the day after it airs on Peacock.
Ahead of the winner being announced on Tuesday's episode, a special finale pre-show will air featuring Ariana Madix and Dylan Efron.
The special will start at 8 p.m. ET on NBC and also stream the following day on Peacock. Madix and Efron will break down Monday's performances and speak with the finalists.
Both NBC and Peacock are owned by NBCUniversal, TODAY’s parent company.
Who Is Competing in the Finale?
Four of the final contestants were announced during the Playoff rounds, while the final two were revealed on Dec. 15.
Aubrey Nicole (Team Reba)Aiden Ross (Team Niall)Jazz McKenzie (Team Bublé) Ralph Edwards (Team Snoop).Dek of Hearts (Team Niall)Max Chambers (Team Bublé)
